docs.title: Examark
docs.text:
Create exams from Markdown and export to Canvas QTI format.

Get Started View on GitHub

docs.title: ✨ Features
docs.text:
• Markdown First

    Write questions in simple, readable Markdown. Clean syntax without headers for better HTML/PDF output.

  • LaTeX Math

    Full equation support with $...$ inline and $$...$$ display math.

  • Image Bundling

    Automatically packages images into Canvas-ready QTI with proper manifests.

  • Canvas Emulator

    Predict import success before uploading. Catch errors early.

  • 8 Question Types

    Multiple choice, true/false, multiple answer, essay, short answer, numeric, matching, and fill-in-blanks.

  • Multiple Export Formats

    Export to Canvas QTI or plain text for printable paper exams.

  • Quarto Integration

    Use with R/Python for dynamic, randomized exam generation.

  • Batch Conversion

    Convert multiple files at once with glob patterns: examark *.md -o output/

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
# No install needed!
npx examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

# Or install globally
npm install -g examark
examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Examark supports project-level configuration through JSON config files.

docs.title: Config Files
docs.text:
Examark searches for config files in this order:

  1. .examarkrc.json (recommended)
  2. examark.config.json

The search starts from the input file's directory and moves up to the filesystem root.

docs.title: Creating a Config File
docs.text:
Create .examarkrc.json in your project root:

{
  "defaultPoints": 2,
  "outputDir": "output",
  "validate": true,
  "title": "Course Quiz"
}

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Type Default Description defaultPoints number 1 Default points for questions without explicit points outputDir string (same as input) Default output directory for generated files validate boolean false Always validate output after conversion title string (from file) Default quiz title override

docs.title: defaultPoints
docs.text:
Set the default point value for questions that don't specify points:

{
  "defaultPoints": 2
}

Questions with explicit points (e.g., [5pts]) are not affected.

docs.title: outputDir
docs.text:
Specify where generated files should be saved:

{
  "outputDir": "qti-packages"
}

The directory is created if it doesn't exist.

docs.title: validate
docs.text:
Always run validation after generating QTI:

{
  "validate": true
}

Equivalent to always using the -v flag.

docs.title: title
docs.text:
Override the quiz title for all conversions:

{
  "title": "Statistics 101 - Quiz"
}

The title from the Markdown file's # Title line is used if not set.

docs.title: CLI Override
docs.text:
Command-line options always take precedence over config file settings:

# Uses config file defaultPoints
examark quiz.md

# CLI overrides config file
examark quiz.md -p 5

docs.title: Example Project Structure
docs.text:
my-course/
├── .examarkrc.json      # Project config
├── exams/
│   ├── midterm.md
│   └── final.md
└── output/              # Generated files go here
    ├── midterm.qti.zip
    └── final.qti.zip

.examarkrc.json:

{
  "defaultPoints": 2,
  "outputDir": "output",
  "validate": true
}

Usage:

cd my-course
examark exams/midterm.md    # Output: output/midterm.qti.zip
examark exams/*.md -o output/  # Batch convert all exams

docs.title: Monorepo Support
docs.text:
For monorepos with multiple courses, place config files in each course directory:

courses/
├── statistics/
│   ├── .examarkrc.json   # Statistics-specific settings
│   └── quizzes/
├── calculus/
│   ├── .examarkrc.json   # Calculus-specific settings
│   └── quizzes/

Each course's quizzes use their own config file.

docs.title: 📦 Release Workflow
docs.text:
We use automated versioning. To release a new version:

  1. Ensure you are on dev branch and clean.

  2. Run the automated release command:

    npm version patch  # v0.4.1 -> v0.4.2
# OR
npm version minor  # v0.4.x -> v0.5.0

    This command automatically: 1. Bumps version in package.json, src/index.ts, _extensions/.../_extension.yml, and README.md. 2. Creates a git commit and tag. 3. Pushes to GitHub. 4. Triggers the GitHub Action to build and release artifacts.

docs.title: Manual Release (Fallback)
docs.text:
If automation fails, run:

bun scripts/sync-version.ts
git add -A
git commit -m "chore: bump version to vX.Y.Z"
git tag vX.Y.Z
git push origin dev --tags

docs.title: Canvas Import Emulator
docs.text: The Examark emulator predicts whether your QTI package will import successfully into Canvas LMS.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: examark emulate-canvas your-package.qti.zip

docs.title: What It Checks
docs.text: Check Severity Description Correct answer defined Error Choice questions must have correctResponse Supported interactions Error Canvas only supports choice, text entry, extended text Image references Error All image files must exist in the package Stem content Error Questions must have non-empty text Option count Error Choice questions need at least 2 options Security Error No XSS vectors (<script>, javascript:) allowed Path Safety Error Resources cannot use ../ traversal Identifier format Warning Special characters may cause issues responseProcessing Warning Manual grading needed if missing

docs.title: Success
docs.text:
🎓 Canvas Import Emulator

📊 Analysis Results:
   Items scanned: 7
   Resources: 8
   Has test structure: Yes

✅ PREDICTION: Canvas import will likely SUCCEED

docs.title: Failure
docs.text:
❌ PREDICTION: Canvas import will likely FAIL

🔴 Canvas Import Blockers:
   • No correct answer defined in items/item_3.xml

🔧 Suggested Fixes:
   → Mark correct answers with [correct], ✓, or **bold**

docs.title: Images Not Showing
docs.text:
If images don't appear in Canvas after import:

  1. Ensure images are in the items/ folder
  2. Check that image paths are relative
  3. For R/Python-generated figures, verify they're rendered before conversion

docs.title: "Couldn't determine correct answers"
docs.text:
This error means Canvas can't find the correctResponse element:

  1. Mark at least one answer as correct in your Markdown
  2. Use [correct] suffix, checkmark ✓, or bold **answer**

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text:
Run Before Import

Always run the emulator before uploading to Canvas to catch issues early.

R/Python Figures

Generate all figures with Quarto/RMarkdown before running Examark.

docs.title: Error: "Failed to import content"
docs.text:
Cause: Usually indicates a malformed manifest or missing resources.

Fix:

# Verify package structure
examark verify your-package.qti.zip

Check that:

  • All referenced files exist in the package
  • imsmanifest.xml is valid XML
  • No special characters in filenames

docs.title: Error: "Unsupported question type"
docs.text:
Cause: Canvas doesn't recognize the QTI interaction type.

Supported types:

QTI Interaction Canvas Type choiceInteraction Multiple Choice textEntryInteraction Fill in the Blank extendedTextInteraction Essay

docs.title: Math Equations Not Rendering
docs.text:
Cause: LaTeX delimiters not converted.

Expected format for Canvas:

Source Canvas Format $x^2$ \(x^2\) $$\sum_{i=1}^n$$ \[\sum_{i=1}^n\]

Examark handles this automatically. If equations still don't render:

  1. Check Canvas has MathJax enabled
  2. Verify no conflicting HTML entities (< vs <)

docs.title: Question Points Not Importing
docs.text:
Cause: Points specified incorrectly in source.

Correct syntax:

## 1. [Essay, 10pts] Explain the concept.
## 2. [5pts] Multiple choice question?

docs.title: Input Formats
docs.text: Examark accepts a simple Markdown-based format for quiz questions. This guide covers the complete syntax for all question types.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Create a file called quiz.md:

Clean Syntax (Recommended)Traditional Syntax 
# My Quiz

1. [MC] What is 2 + 2? [2pts]
a) 3
b) 4 [x]
c) 5

# My Quiz

## 1. What is 2 + 2?
a) 3
b) **4** ✓
c) 5

Convert to Canvas QTI:

examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

docs.title: Syntax Styles
docs.text: Examark supports two syntax styles. You can mix them in the same file.

docs.title: Clean Syntax (Recommended)
docs.text:
Use numbered questions without ## headers. Better for Quarto HTML/PDF output:

1. [TF] The sky is blue. [2pts]
a) True [x]
b) False

2. [MC] What is variance? [3pts]
a) Sum of values // Incorrect feedback
b) Average squared deviation [x] // Correct!
c) Standard deviation

Requirements for clean syntax:

  • Must have a type marker [TF], [MC], etc. OR
  • Must have points [Npts] OR
  • Must follow a section header

docs.title: Traditional Syntax
docs.text:
Use ## N. headers (original format):

## 1. What is the capital of France? [2 pts]

## 2. [TF] The Earth is round. → True

## 3. [Essay, 10pts] Explain your reasoning.

docs.title: Quiz Title
docs.text:
The first # Title line becomes the quiz title:

# Statistics Midterm Exam

docs.title: Sections
docs.text:
Group questions into sections:

# Section: Multiple Choice

1. [MC] Question one... [2pts]

2. [MC] Question two... [2pts]

# Section: Essay Questions

3. [Essay] Essay question... [10pts]

docs.title: Question Types
docs.text:
Examark supports 8 question types. Use type markers in brackets:

Type Markers (case-insensitive) Multiple Choice [MC] (default if no marker) True/False [TF], [TrueFalse], [True/False], [T/F] Multiple Answers [MA], [MultiAns], [SelectAll], [MultipleAnswers] Short Answer [Short], [ShortAnswer], [FillIn], [FITB] Numeric [Numeric], [Num], [Number] Essay [Essay], [LongAnswer], [OpenEnded] Matching [Match], [Matching] Fill-in-Multiple-Blanks [FMB], [MultiBlanks], [FillInMultiple]

docs.title: Multiple Choice (Default)
docs.text:
The default type. Mark the correct answer with one of the supported markers.

## 1. What is 2 + 2? [2 pts]

a) 3
b) **4** ✓
c) 5
d) 6

Supported Answer Markers:

Marker Example Notes [x] b) Answer [x] Clean syntax (recommended) **Bold** b) **Answer** Most visual ✓ b) Answer ✓ With checkmark [correct] b) Answer [correct] Quarto-friendly * prefix *b) Answer Traditional format

All markers can be combined. These all mark option b as correct:

b) Answer [x]
b) **Correct answer**
b) Correct answer ✓
b) Answer [correct]
*b) Answer

docs.title: Inline Feedback
docs.text:
Add feedback for each answer option using //:

1. [MC] What is 2 + 2? [2pts]
a) 3 // Close, but not quite
b) 4 [x] // Correct! 2 + 2 = 4
c) 5 // Too high

Feedback appears in Canvas after students submit their answers.

docs.title: True / False
docs.text:
Use [TF] tag or arrow syntax.

Method 1: Arrow Syntax (Recommended)

Single-line format with answer in the header:

## 2. [TF] The sky is blue. → True

## 3. [TF] Water boils at 50°C. → False

Method 2: Standard Options

## 4. [TF] The Earth is flat.

*True
False

Arrow Formats: Use → True, → False, -> True, or -> False.

docs.title: Multiple Answers
docs.text:
Use [MultiAns] for questions with multiple correct answers.

## 5. [MultiAns, 4pts] Which are primary colors?

*a) Red
b) Orange
*c) Blue
d) Green
*e) Yellow

Mark all correct answers with * prefix.

docs.title: Short Answer
docs.text:
Use [Short] for fill-in-the-blank questions.

## 6. [Short] The capital of France is

Answer: Paris

Multiple Accepted Answers:

## 7. [Short] What is the SI unit of force?

Answer: Newton
Answer: N
Answer: newton

Canvas matches case-insensitively.

docs.title: Numeric
docs.text:
Use [Numeric] with a tolerance value.

## 8. [Numeric, 3pts] Calculate the mean of 2, 4, 6, 8, 10.

Answer: 6 ± 0.1

Tolerance Formats:

Format Meaning ± 0 Exact match required ± 0.01 Allow small rounding error ± 5 Allow range of values

docs.title: Essay
docs.text:
Use [Essay] for open-ended questions. No answer options needed.

## 9. [Essay, 10pts] Explain the process of photosynthesis.

Describe at least three key steps in your explanation.
Include the role of chlorophyll and sunlight.

Everything after the header becomes the question stem.

docs.title: Matching
docs.text:
Use [Match] for matching questions. Define pairs with :: or =>:

## 10. [Match, 4pts] Match statistics terms with definitions.

- Mean :: Average of all values
- Median :: Middle value when sorted
- Mode :: Most frequent value
- Range :: Difference between max and min

Alternative syntax with =>:

1. [Match] Match the formula to its name. [3pts]
- $\bar{x}$ => Sample mean
- $s^2$ => Sample variance
- $\sigma$ => Population standard deviation

docs.title: Fill-in-Multiple-Blanks
docs.text:
Use [FMB] for questions with multiple blanks:

## 11. [FMB, 5pts] Complete the regression equation.

The simple linear regression equation is [slope] times x plus [intercept].

[slope]: beta_1, β1, b1
[intercept]: beta_0, β0, b0

Blank definitions:

  • Define blanks at the end with [blank_name]: answer1, answer2, ...
  • Multiple accepted answers are comma-separated
  • Reference blanks in text with [blank_name]

docs.title: Default Points
docs.text: Questions default to 1 point unless specified.

docs.title: Inline Points
docs.text:
Use [N pts] or [Npts] syntax:

## 1. Easy question [1 pt]

## 2. Medium question [5 pts]

## 3. Hard question [10pts]

docs.title: Combined with Type
docs.text:
## 4. [Essay, 10pts] Describe...

## 5. [MultiAns, 4pts] Select all...

## 6. [Numeric, 3pts] Calculate...

docs.title: LaTeX Math
docs.text: Both inline and display math are supported.

docs.title: Inline Math
docs.text:
Use single dollar signs:

## 1. In regression, what does $\beta_1$ represent?

The formula $y = mx + b$ describes a line.

docs.title: Display Math
docs.text:
Use double dollar signs:

## 2. Which formula shows the quadratic equation?

$$x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

a) Pythagorean theorem
b) **Quadratic formula** ✓
c) Euler's identity

docs.title: Canvas Compatibility
docs.text:
Examark automatically converts:

Markdown Canvas $...$ \(...\) $$...$$ \[...\]

Canvas renders math using MathJax.

docs.title: Images
docs.text: Images are automatically bundled into the QTI package.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
## 1. What does this graph show?

![Graph Description](assets/graph.png)

a) Linear growth
b) **Exponential growth** ✓
c) No relationship

docs.title: Supported Formats
docs.text: Format Extension Best For PNG .png Charts, screenshots JPEG .jpg, .jpeg Photos SVG .svg Vector graphics GIF .gif Animations WebP .webp Modern format

docs.title: Path Requirements
docs.text:
• Use relative paths from your Markdown file
  • Recommended: Keep images in an assets/ subfolder
  • Paths are case-sensitive
quiz/
├── my-quiz.md
└── assets/
    ├── chart1.png
    ├── diagram.svg
    └── photo.jpg

docs.title: What Happens
docs.text:
Examark:

  1. Finds all ![alt](path) references
  2. Copies images into the QTI package
  3. Generates imsmanifest.xml
  4. Creates proper <img> tags in the QTI XML

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
Include code examples in questions:

## 1. What does this code output?

```python
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("World"))
```

a) Hello World
b) **Hello, World!** ✓
c) greet(World)
d) Error

Code is preserved with syntax highlighting in Canvas.

docs.title: Solution Blocks
docs.text:
Examark ignores solution content:

<div class="solution">
  This content will NOT appear in Canvas.
</div>

Or use the proof class:

<div class="proof">
  Step-by-step solution...
</div>

Quarto Users: Use ::: blocks:

::: {.solution}
This is hidden in Canvas export.
:::

# Section: Concepts

1. [MC] Which measure is most affected by outliers? [2pts]
a) Mode
b) Median
c) Mean [x] // This is the correct answer

Answer: 1.5 ± 0.01

4. [Match, 4pts] Match terms with definitions.
- Mean => Average of values
- Median => Middle value
- Mode => Most frequent

# Section: Written Response

5. [Essay, 10pts] Explain correlation vs causation.

Provide an example of a spurious correlation.

a) Mode
b) Median

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Get up and running with Examark in minutes.

docs.title: Quick Start (No Install Needed)
docs.text:
Run Examark directly using npx (requires Node.js):

npx examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

This downloads and runs Examark on-demand. Perfect for trying it out!

docs.title: Permanent Install
docs.text:
Mac (Homebrew)Mac/Linux (npm)WindowsDeveloper

Recommended for Mac users:

brew tap data-wise/tap
brew install examark

Homebrew handles the Node.js dependency automatically.

npm install -g examark

Requires Node.js 18+.

Never used Node.js before? No problem! Here's the complete guide:

  1. Download Node.js from nodejs.org — click the big green "LTS" button
  2. Run the installer — accept all defaults, click Next through everything
  3. Open Command Prompt — search "cmd" in Start menu
  4. Verify Node installed: type node --version and press Enter
  5. Install examark:
npm install -g examark
  1. Verify it worked:
examark --version

Quickest Option

Skip the global install and just use npx examark quiz.md — it runs without installing!

For contributing or modifying the source:

git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/examark.git
cd examark
npm install
npm run build
npm link

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command Purpose examark <file> -o <out.zip> Convert Markdown to QTI examark <file> -f text Export as printable text examark *.md -o output/ Batch convert multiple files examark verify <pkg> Validate package structure examark verify <pkg> --strict Strict validation for New Quizzes examark emulate-canvas <pkg> Simulate Canvas import examark check <file> Lint input file examark <file> --preview Preview parsed questions

docs.title: examark (convert)
docs.text:
Usage:

examark <input> [options]
examark <pattern> -o <directory>   # Batch mode

What it does:

  • Parses your Markdown file for questions
  • Generates QTI 1.2 XML for Canvas Classic Quizzes
  • Bundles images with imsmanifest.xml
  • Creates a .qti.zip package (or .txt for text export)

When to use:

Converting your Markdown quiz files for Canvas import or printable exams.

Options:

Option Description -o, --output <path> Output file or directory (batch mode) -f, --format <type> Output format: qti (default) or text -v, --validate Validate output after generating -p, --points <n> Default points per question -t, --title <title> Override quiz title --preview Preview parsed questions, no file created --no-answers Exclude answer key from text export

Examples:

# Basic conversion to QTI
examark quiz.md

# Custom output path
examark quiz.md -o output/my-quiz.qti.zip

# Export as printable text
examark quiz.md -f text

# Text export without answers
examark quiz.md -f text --no-answers

# Batch convert all markdown files
examark *.md -o output/

# Set default points
examark quiz.md -p 2

# Preview without generating
examark quiz.md --preview

docs.title: Batch Conversion
docs.text:
Convert multiple files at once using glob patterns:

# Convert all .md files in current directory
examark *.md -o output/

# Convert files from specific folder
examark exams/*.md -o qti-packages/

# Convert specific pattern
examark midterm-*.md -o midterms/

Notes:

  • Output directory is created if it doesn't exist
  • Each file is named based on input: quiz.md → quiz.qti.zip
  • Errors in one file don't stop processing of others
  • Summary shows success/failure counts

docs.title: Text Export
docs.text:
Export quizzes as plain text for paper exams:

examark quiz.md -f text
examark quiz.md -f text -o exam.txt
examark quiz.md -f text --no-answers

Output includes:

  • Quiz title and header
  • Name/Date fields for students
  • All questions formatted for printing
  • Answer key at the end (unless --no-answers)

Example output:

STATISTICS QUIZ 1
Name: _________________________  Date: _________

1. [2 pts] What is the mean of 2, 4, 6?
   a) Three
   b) Four
   c) Five

2. [1 pt] TRUE or FALSE: Variance can be negative.

---
ANSWER KEY
1. b
2. False

docs.title: verify
docs.text:
Usage:

examark verify <path> [options]

What it does:

  • Validates manifest structure
  • Checks all referenced resources exist
  • Validates XML syntax
  • Reports missing or malformed files

Options:

Option Description --strict Enable strict validation for New Quizzes compatibility

When to use:

Checking an existing QTI package before Canvas import. Use --strict for Canvas New Quizzes.

Examples:

# Standard validation
examark verify quiz.qti.zip
examark verify ./qti-folder/

# Strict validation for New Quizzes
examark verify quiz.qti.zip --strict

Strict Mode Checks:

When --strict is enabled, additional validations are performed:

  • Assessment must have ident attribute
  • Each item must have itemmetadata with qtimetadata
  • Each item must have question_type metadata
  • Each item must have points_possible metadata
  • Each item must have resprocessing element (for auto-graded questions)
  • Item identifiers must be alphanumeric with underscores only

docs.title: emulate-canvas
docs.text:
Usage:

examark emulate-canvas <path> [options]

What it does:

  • Simulates Canvas LMS import process
  • Validates QTI 1.2 compatibility
  • Checks for duplicate IDs
  • Predicts import success or failure

Options:

Option Description --strict Enable strict validation for New Quizzes compatibility

When to use:

Before uploading to Canvas, especially for complex quizzes. Use --strict if targeting Canvas New Quizzes.

Examples:

# Emulate Classic Quizzes import
examark emulate-canvas quiz.qti.zip

# Emulate New Quizzes import (stricter)
examark emulate-canvas quiz.qti.zip --strict

Output includes:

  • Item count and structure analysis
  • Canvas-specific validation checks
  • Success/failure prediction
  • Actionable fix suggestions

docs.title: check (lint)
docs.text:
Usage:

examark check <input>
# or
examark lint <input>

What it does:

  • Validates Markdown syntax
  • Checks question formatting
  • Reports missing answer markers
  • Identifies structural issues

When to use:

Before conversion to catch input errors early.

Example:

examark check quiz.md

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for Examark.

docs.title: Quick Diagnosis
docs.text:
Run these commands to check your setup:

# Check Examark is installed
examark --version

# Validate your input file
examark check quiz.md

# Test package structure
examark verify quiz.qti.zip

docs.title: Node.js version error
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: Examark requires Node.js 18+

Solution:

# Check your Node version
node --version

# Install Node 18+ via nvm
nvm install 18
nvm use 18

docs.title: Command not found after npm link
docs.text:
Symptom: zsh: command not found: examark

Solution:

# Rebuild and relink
npm run build
npm link

# Or use npx
npx examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

docs.title: No questions found
docs.text:
Symptom: Warning: No questions found in input file

Cause: Questions must use ## N. format (double hash with number and period).

Solution:

# Wrong (single hash)
# 1. What is 2+2?

# Correct (double hash)
## 1. What is 2+2?

docs.title: Images not bundling
docs.text:
Symptom: Images appear broken in Canvas after import

Cause: Image paths are relative to the Markdown file location.

Solution:

# Ensure images exist at the referenced path
ls -la assets/

# Use relative paths in your Markdown
![Chart](assets/chart.png)

docs.title: "Couldn't determine correct answers"
docs.text:
Symptom: Canvas shows warning during import

Cause: Answer markers not recognized.

Solution: Use one of these markers for correct answers:

Marker Example **Bold** 2) **Answer** ✓ 2) Answer ✓ [correct] 2) Answer [correct]

docs.title: Import completes but no questions appear
docs.text:
Symptom: Canvas says import succeeded but question bank is empty

Solution:

  1. Navigate to Quizzes → Manage Question Banks
  2. Check for a bank named after your quiz title
  3. If still missing, run the Canvas emulator to diagnose:
examark emulate-canvas quiz.qti.zip

docs.title: Quarto Exam Extension
docs.text: Examark includes a powerful Quarto extension that allows you to author exams in Quarto (.qmd) and export them to multiple formats, including Canvas-ready QTI, HTML previews, printable PDFs, and more.

docs.title: Method 1: GitHub Installation (Recommended)
docs.text:
Install directly from the GitHub repository:

quarto add Data-Wise/examark

This will:

  1. Download the extension from GitHub
  2. Create _extensions/exam/ in your project
  3. Prompt you to trust the extension

Pin to a Version

For reproducible builds, install a specific release: 

quarto add Data-Wise/examark@v0.6.1

docs.title: Method 2: Local Installation
docs.text:
If you have the repository cloned:

cp -r examark/_extensions/exam your-project/_extensions/

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
ls _extensions/exam/
# Should show: _extension.yml  exam-filter.lua  exam.scss  qti-post-render.js

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Create a .qmd file with the exam-qti format:
---
title: "My Quiz"
format:
  exam-qti: default
---

## 1. What is 2 + 2?

a) 3
b) **4** [correct]
c) 5
  1. Render to Markdown:
quarto render quiz.qmd --to exam-qti
  1. Convert to Canvas QTI:
examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

LaTeX Math Works Automatically

The exam-qti format preserves $...$ and $$...$$ math notation by default. No extra configuration needed!

docs.title: Dynamic Exams with R & Python
docs.text: This advanced tutorial covers programmatic exam generation using R and Python code in Quarto documents.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Dynamic exams let you:

  • Randomize values — Each student sees different numbers
  • Compute answers — Correct answers calculated from the problem
  • Generate figures — Create unique plots for each version
  • Scale easily — One source file → many exam versions

docs.title: Basic Setup
docs.text:
Every dynamic exam starts with a setup chunk:

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
# CRITICAL: Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(42)  # Change for different versions

# Load packages
library(knitr)

# Configure chunks
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  echo = FALSE,      # Hide code
  warning = FALSE,   # Hide warnings
  message = FALSE    # Hide messages
)
```

docs.title: Random Values Pattern
docs.text:
# Generate random data
sample_size <- sample(20:50, 1)
sample_mean <- round(runif(1, 50, 100), 1)
sample_sd <- round(runif(1, 5, 15), 1)

# Compute derived values
std_error <- sample_sd / sqrt(sample_size)
t_critical <- qt(0.975, sample_size - 1)
margin_error <- t_critical * std_error

# Confidence interval bounds
ci_lower <- round(sample_mean - margin_error, 2)
ci_upper <- round(sample_mean + margin_error, 2)

docs.title: Creating Plausible Distractors
docs.text:
Good distractors are common student errors:

correct_answer <- ci_upper - ci_lower  # Width of CI

# Distractor 1: Forgot to multiply by 2
wrong_1 <- margin_error

# Distractor 2: Used wrong t-value
wrong_2 <- round(1.96 * std_error * 2, 2)

# Distractor 3: Random plausible value
wrong_3 <- round(correct_answer * runif(1, 0.5, 0.8), 2)

docs.title: Full Question Example
docs.text:
```{r ci-setup, include=FALSE}
set.seed(42)
n <- sample(25:40, 1)
xbar <- round(runif(1, 70, 90), 1)
s <- round(runif(1, 8, 15), 1)
se <- s / sqrt(n)
t_crit <- round(qt(0.975, n-1), 3)
me <- round(t_crit * se, 2)
ci_lower <- round(xbar - me, 2)
ci_upper <- round(xbar + me, 2)
```

## 1. Confidence Interval [3 pts]

A sample of n = `r n` students has a mean score of $\bar{x}$ = `r xbar` with standard deviation s = `r s`.

Calculate the 95% confidence interval for the population mean.

a) (`r ci_lower - 2`, `r ci_upper + 2`)
b) (`r ci_lower + 1`, `r ci_upper - 1`)
c) **(`r ci_lower`, `r ci_upper`)** [correct]
d) (`r xbar - s`, `r xbar + s`)

::: {.solution}
SE = s/√n = `r s`/√`r n` = `r round(se, 3)`

t* = `r t_crit` (df = `r n-1`)

ME = t* × SE = `r t_crit` × `r round(se, 3)` = `r me`

CI = (`r xbar` ± `r me`) = (`r ci_lower`, `r ci_upper`)
:::

```{r hist-data, include=FALSE}
scores <- rnorm(100, mean = 75, sd = 12)
```


## 2. Distribution Shape [2 pts]

Based on the histogram above, this distribution is:

a) Strongly positively skewed
b) Strongly negatively skewed
c) **Approximately symmetric** [correct]
d) Uniform

```{r regression-setup, include=FALSE}
set.seed(42)
n <- 50
hours <- runif(n, 1, 10)
scores <- 45 + 5 * hours + rnorm(n, 0, 8)
model <- lm(scores ~ hours)
b0 <- round(coef(model)[1], 1)
b1 <- round(coef(model)[2], 2)
r_sq <- round(summary(model)$r.squared, 3)
```

```{r scatterplot, fig.cap="Study Hours vs Exam Score"}
abline(model, col = "red", lwd = 2)
mtext(paste0("ŷ = ", b0, " + ", b1, "x"), 
      side = 3, line = 0, cex = 0.9)
```

docs.title: Strategy 1: Multiple Seeds
docs.text:
# build-versions.sh

for seed in 100 200 300; do
    sed -i '' "s/set.seed([0-9]*)/set.seed($seed)/" exam.qmd
    quarto render exam.qmd --to exam-gfm
    mv exam.md "version-${seed}.md"
    examark "version-${seed}.md" -o "version-${seed}.qti.zip"

docs.text:
Create a wrapper script:

# render_versions.R
versions <- c("A" = 100, "B" = 200, "C" = 300)

for (v in names(versions)) {
    quarto::quarto_render(
        "exam.qmd",
        output_file = paste0("exam-", v, ".md"),
        execute_params = list(seed = versions[[v]])
    )
}

With YAML parameters:

---
params:
  seed: 42
---

set.seed(params$seed)

Ensure generated answers are valid:

repeat {

docs.title: Distractor Quality Check
docs.text:
generate_distractors <- function(correct, n = 3) {
  distractors <- c()
  while (length(distractors) < n) {
    d <- correct + sample(c(-1, 1), 1) * runif(1, 1, 5)
    d <- round(d, 2)

    # Ensure distractor is different from correct and others
    if (abs(d - correct) > 0.5 && !d %in% distractors) {
      distractors <- c(distractors, d)
    }
  }
  distractors
}

docs.text:
• Set deterministic seed

  • Verify all computed answers are reasonable
  • Check figure generation works
  • Preview HTML before export
  • Run Canvas emulator on each version
  • Document which seed produces which version

docs.title: Different Results Each Render
docs.text:
Cause: Seed not set or set after random operations

Fix: Put set.seed() at the very top of setup chunk

docs.title: Figures Not Embedded
docs.text:
Cause: Figure path issues

Fix: Ensure figures are in the same directory or use:

knitr::opts_chunk$set(fig.path = "figures/")

docs.title: Math Not Rendering
docs.text:
Cause: Missing variant setting

Fix:

format:
  exam-gfm:
    variant: +tex_math_dollars

docs.title: Inline R Code Shows Raw
docs.text:
Cause: Quarto processing issue

Fix: Ensure backticks are proper and R code is valid

docs.title: Your First Quiz
docs.text: Create and import a quiz into Canvas in under 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Markdown File
docs.text:
Create a file called quiz.md with this content:

# My First Quiz

1. [MC] What is the capital of France? [2pts]
a) London
b) Paris [x]
c) Berlin
d) Madrid

2. [TF] The Earth is flat. [1pt]
a) True
b) False [x]

3. [Essay, 5pts] Describe your favorite book.

That's it! The syntax is:

  • # Title — Quiz title
  • 1. [MC] — Question number and type (MC = Multiple Choice)
  • [2pts] — Point value
  • [x] — Marks the correct answer

docs.title: Step 2: Convert to QTI
docs.text:
Open your terminal and run:

npx examark quiz.md -o quiz.qti.zip

Output

✓ Generated QTI 1.2 Package: quiz.qti.zip
  • 3 questions
  • 0 sections
  • Format: Canvas Classic Quizzes compatible

docs.title: Step 3: Import into Canvas
docs.text:
1. Go to your Canvas course
  2. Click Settings → Import Course Content
  3. Select QTI .zip file
  4. Choose your quiz.qti.zip file
  5. Click Import

docs.title: Step 4: Verify and Publish
docs.text:
1. Go to Quizzes in your course
  2. Find "My First Quiz"
  3. Click to preview
  4. Click Publish when ready

docs.title: R & Quarto Integration Tutorial
docs.text: This tutorial walks you through creating a statistics exam using Quarto and R, then exporting it to Canvas.

docs.title: Why Use Quarto?
docs.text: Feature Benefit Dynamic Content Generate random numbers for unique question variants Reproducibility Version control your exam source code Embedded Plots Auto-generate and embed R/Python plots Multi-Format One source → PDF, HTML, Canvas QTI

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Quarto installed (≥ 1.4.0)
  • R installed (for dynamic questions)
  • Examark installed globally

docs.title: Step 1: Install the Extension
docs.text:
quarto add Data-Wise/examark

This creates _extensions/exam/ in your project with the Lua filters and styling.

docs.title: Step 2: Create Your First Exam
docs.text:
Create a file called midterm.qmd:

---
title: "Statistics Midterm"
format:
  exam-gfm:
    variant: +tex_math_dollars
exam:
  solutions: false
  default-points: 2
---

# Section: Descriptive Statistics

## 1. Mean Calculation [2 pts]

What is the mean of: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50?

a) 25
b) **30** [correct]
c) 35
d) 40

## 2. [TF] The median is resistant to outliers. → True

docs.title: Step 3: Render to Markdown
docs.text:
quarto render midterm.qmd --to exam-gfm

This creates midterm.md with properly formatted questions for Examark.

docs.title: Step 4: Convert to Canvas QTI
docs.text: examark midterm.md -o midterm.qti.zip

docs.title: Step 5: Upload to Canvas
docs.text:
1. Go to your Canvas course
  2. Navigate to Settings → Import Course Content
  3. Select QTI .zip file
  4. Upload midterm.qti.zip
  5. Select import options and click Import

Your questions will appear in Quizzes → Question Banks.

docs.title: Adding R Code for Dynamic Questions
Random Values
docs.text:
Use R inline code to generate unique values:

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
set.seed(42)  # For reproducibility
values <- sample(10:50, 5)
correct_mean <- mean(values)
```

## 1. Calculate the Mean [2 pts]

Find the mean of: `r paste(values, collapse=", ")`

a) `r correct_mean - 5`
b) **`r correct_mean`** [correct]
c) `r correct_mean + 5`
d) `r correct_mean + 10`

docs.title: Generated Plots
docs.text:
Embed R-generated figures directly:

```{r histogram, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Score Distribution"}
hist(rnorm(100, mean=75, sd=10), 
     main="Exam Scores", 
     xlab="Score",
     col="steelblue")
```

## 3. Histogram Shape [2 pts]

What is the shape of the distribution shown above?

a) Positively skewed
b) Negatively skewed  
c) **Approximately normal** [correct]
d) Uniform

docs.title: Computed Answers
docs.text:
Calculate correct answers programmatically:

```{r regression, include=FALSE}
x <- 1:10
y <- 2*x + 3 + rnorm(10, 0, 0.5)
model <- lm(y ~ x)
slope <- round(coef(model)[2], 2)
```

## 4. Regression Slope [3 pts]

Given the regression output, the slope is approximately:

a) `r slope - 0.5`
b) **`r slope`** [correct]
c) `r slope + 0.5`
d) `r slope + 1`

docs.title: Version Strategy
docs.text:
Use different seeds to create parallel exam versions:

# Version A
set.seed(100)

# Version B  
set.seed(200)

# Version C
set.seed(300)

docs.title: Automation Script
docs.text:
Create a shell script build_exams.sh:

#!/bin/bash

# Build Version A
sed -i '' 's/set.seed([0-9]*)/set.seed(100)/' midterm.qmd
quarto render midterm.qmd --to exam-gfm
mv midterm.md version-a.md
examark version-a.md -o version-a.qti.zip

# Build Version B
sed -i '' 's/set.seed([0-9]*)/set.seed(200)/' midterm.qmd
quarto render midterm.qmd --to exam-gfm
mv midterm.md version-b.md
examark version-b.md -o version-b.qti.zip

# Verify both
examark verify version-a.qti.zip
examark verify version-b.qti.zip

docs.title: 1. Hiding Solutions
docs.text:
Wrap solutions in a .solution div – they're automatically hidden:

## 1. What is the variance formula?

a) Wrong
b) **Correct** [correct]

::: {.solution}
The variance formula divides by n-1 for sample variance...
:::

docs.title: 2. Use [correct] Markers
docs.text:
The [correct] suffix is more reliable than bold or checkmarks when using R code:

a) `r value_a`
b) `r value_b` [correct]
c) `r value_c`

docs.title: 3. Preview Before Export
docs.text:
Always preview in HTML first:

quarto render midterm.qmd --to exam-html
open midterm.html  # Check formatting

docs.title: 4. Verify the QTI Package
docs.text:
Run the Canvas emulator before uploading:

examark emulate-canvas midterm.qti.zip

docs.title: Complete Workflow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[midterm.qmd] -->|quarto render| B[midterm.md]
    B -->|examark| C[midterm.qti.zip]
    C -->|upload| D[Canvas]

    A -->|quarto render| E[midterm.pdf]
    A -->|quarto render| F[midterm.html]

    E --> G[Print for Students]
    F --> H[Preview/Review]
    D --> I[Online Quiz]

docs.title: R Code Not Executing
docs.text:
Ensure you have:

  1. R installed
  2. knitr package installed: install.packages("knitr")
  3. Code chunks configured properly

docs.title: Figures Not Appearing in Canvas
docs.text:
1. Check that figures are in the same directory as the .md file
  2. Verify the QTI package includes them: unzip -l exam.qti.zip
  3. Use relative paths in your Markdown

docs.title: Math Rendering Issues
docs.text:
1. Use variant: +tex_math_dollars in your YAML
  2. Ensure Canvas has MathJax enabled (course settings)
  3. Test with simple math first: $x^2$

docs.title: VS Code Snippets
docs.text: Examark includes built-in snippets for fast exam authoring in VS Code, Positron, and VS Codium.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The snippets are included in the repository. To use them:

  1. Clone or download Examark
  2. Open the folder in VS Code/Positron
  3. Start typing a prefix and press Tab

Project-Level Snippets

Copy .vscode/examark.code-snippets to any project to get snippets there too.

docs.title: Question Types
docs.text: Prefix Expands To mcq Multiple choice (4 options) mcq5 Multiple choice (5 options) tfq True/False question (compact) tf True/False with explicit options essay Essay question short Short answer with auto-grading numeric Numeric with tolerance multians Multiple answer (select all that apply)

docs.title: Structure
docs.text: Prefix Expands To examhead Exam pool + section headers section Section header pool Question pool header

docs.title: Figures & Images
docs.text: Prefix Expands To mcqimg Question with embedded image rfig R code chunk for figures (Quarto) pyfig Python code chunk for figures (Quarto)

docs.title: Other
docs.text: Prefix Expands To solution Solution block (hidden in student version) examyaml Quarto YAML header imath Inline LaTeX math dmath Display LaTeX block statq Statistics formula question

docs.title: Usage Example
docs.text:
Type mcq and press Tab:

## 1. Question text [2 pts]

a) Option A
b) Option B
c) **Correct Answer** ✓
d) Option D

Use Tab to jump between placeholders.

docs.title: Customizing
docs.text:
Edit .vscode/examark.code-snippets to add your own snippets or modify existing ones.

"My Custom Question": {
  "prefix": "myq",
  "body": [
    "## ${1:1}. ${2:Question} [${3:2} pts]",
    "",
    "a) ${4:A}",
    "b) **${5:B}** ✓"
  ],
  "description": "My custom question type"
}
